title: 105_hr2233
content: The "Coral Reef Conservation Act of 1997" aims to preserve, sustain, and restore coral reef ecosystems by supporting conservation programs, providing financial resources, and establishing a mechanism for collecting donations from the private sector. The Act defines "coral" as species of the phylum Cnidaria, including various orders such as Antipatharia, Scleractinia, Gorgonacea, and Hydrocorallina. It also defines "coral reef" as a reef composed primarily of Scleractinia skeletal material, and "coral reef ecosystem" as the complex of species associated with coral reefs that function as an ecological unit in nature. The term "corals and coral products" refers to living or dead specimens, parts, or derivatives of species in the phylum Cnidaria. Conservation involves methods to preserve coral reefs and associated species as diverse, viable, and self-perpetuating ecosystems. Management strategies for marine protected areas and resources in line with relevant acts; law enforcement, conflict resolution, community outreach, and education. The "Fund" refers to the Coral Reef Conservation Fund, and the "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Commerce. SEC. 4. CORAL REEF CONSERVATION ASSISTANCE. The Secretary will use funds from the Fund to provide grants for coral reef conservation projects with approved proposals. Relevant authorities or organizations with expertise can submit project proposals including project details and qualifications. The Secretary will review project proposals to determine eligibility for funding under the Act. Qualifications of individuals, estimated funds and time needed, support from appropriate representatives, matching funding details, and any other necessary information will be considered. The Secretary will consult with relevant authorities and conduct a merit-based peer review of project proposals within 6 months of submission. The Secretary will conduct a peer review and approve or disapprove project proposals based on merit review. Approval criteria include enhancing conservation programs, addressing conflicts near coral reefs, and ensuring compliance with relevant laws. Notification of approval or disapproval will be provided to the submitter and relevant government entities. The Secretary prioritizes projects that promote sustainable development and long-term coral reef conservation. Grantees must provide periodic reports as required by the Secretary. The Secretary requires periodic reports for project evaluation. Non-Federal matching funds must cover at least 50% of project costs for approval. SEC. 5. CORAL REEF CONSERVATION FUND. Establishment of the Coral Reef Conservation Fund in the Treasury's general fund to receive deposits from the Secretary of the Treasury. The Fund will consist of monetary donations and other appropriated amounts. The Secretary can use the Fund to provide assistance without further appropriation, with a limit of 3 percent for administration. Acceptance and use of monetary donations are allowed by the Secretary. The Secretary can accept and use monetary donations for assistance under section 4, with amounts transferred to the Treasury for deposit into the Fund. Authorization of appropriations for the Fund is set at $1,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2002, as per the Act passed by the House of Representatives on November 13, 1997.
